sp.speaker: M●r.
sp.p: Be't as my fate shall please, my loss I value but as goods lent me, now to be paid back, but that which most afflicts my sorrowful soul, is that my friends have ventured largely with me, especially my sister, who I fear will brook that ill which I with patience bear.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Place him below the hatches as our prisoner, and now to part our purchase bravely won, even with the hazard of our dearest lives.

sp.speaker: Cli●.
sp.p: The danger passed still makes the purchase sweet. Come first drink round my merry mates, that done, divide in peace what we by war have 〈◊〉Exeunt

div.stage: Enter young Mr. Forrest, like a captain of a ship, with sailors and mariners, entering with a flourish.

sp.speaker: Young For:
sp.p: Gentlemen, and my merry mates at sea, those special savours you have crowned me with, can never be deserved upon my part, so weak is my ability and knowledge in navigation and exploits at sea; yet since your loves so far exceeds my worth, that of an unexperienced gentleman you have preferred me above many other, to be your captain, and command your ship, I hope to bear myself so even and upright in this my charge, that it shall not repent you of the least honour to my grace decreed.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.p: Our captain being lately slain in fight, we by your valour scaped our enemies, and made their ship our prize, since we first knew you all our attempts succeeded prosperously, and heaven hath better blessed us for your sake.

sp.speaker: 2. Mar.
sp.p: When first we took you to our fellowship, we had a poor bark of some fifteen tun, and that was all our riches, but since then we have taken many a rich prize from Spain, and got a gallant vessel stoutly maned, and well provided of ordnance and small shot, men and ammunition, that we now dare cope with any carack that does trade for Spain.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: We dare do any thing that stands with justice, our country's honour, and the reputation of our own names; but amongst all our spoils I wonder we have scaped the valiant pirates that are so much renowned upon the sea, that were a conquest worth the hazarding, besides a thousand pounds reward proposed to that adventurer that can bring them in, my peace and pardon though a man condemned, is by the proclamation ratified.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.p: The ocean scarce can bear their outrages, they are so violent, confounding all, and sparing none, not their own countrymen, we could not do our country greater service than in their pursuit to engage our lives.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: I could we meet those rovers on the sea, so famous for their piracies and thefts, so feared of all that trade for merchandise, so proud of their strong vessels and stout ging, that man her with their proud artillery that thunders wrack to every ship alike; o with what ardour and enflamed desire would we in the mid sea encounter them! Climb to the main-top, boy, see what you ken there.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I shall, I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: We seek for purchase, but we take't from foes, and such is held amongst us lawful spoil; but such as are our friends and countrymen we succour with the best supply we have of victuals or munition being distressed.

sp.speaker: Above, boy.
sp.p: Ho there.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.p: Ha boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A sail.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.p: Whence is she?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That I cannot ken; she appears to me out of our hemisphere no bigger than a crow.

sp.speaker: Young For:
sp.p: Descry her better, o that it were the desperate pirates ship, on that condition we might grapple straight, and try our desperate fortunes on even change, but I that have been born to misery can never be so happy; o my fate when shall I pass away this tedious night,
sp.l: Or when my stars will you burn out more bright.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Boatswain, ho.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.p: Whence comes thy ken?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: She makes from South to West.

sp.speaker: 2. Mar.
sp.p: How bears she?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To the leeward .

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: Clap on more sails and quickly fetch her up. What colours bears her main-top?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: She's not so near in ken.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: Discover her more amply, now my mates prepare yourselves, for it may be some prize; you master gunner load your ordnance well, and look well to your cartridges and fire; see that your gunner room be clear and free, your matches bear good coals, your priming powder pounded, not dank; next charge your murderers for fear of boarding: steersman part the helm, and bear up towards them, be they friends or foes we'll hale them if heaven please; and master you heed well your compass, boatswain with your whistle command the sailors to the upper deck to know their quarters, and to hear their charge.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Captain, ho.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: The news? whence is her flag?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: She bears the cross of England and st. George.

sp.speaker: Young For:
sp.p: Then she's a friend for England, and st. George our gallant vessel in her main-top bears, and all our preparations needless then.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Arm rather, for I see them from a far make all provision for a present fight, they have managed their hatches, hung their pendants out, displayed their ensigns, up with all their fights, their matches in their cocks, their smoking linstocks are likewise fired within their gunners hands; and hark they shoot already. A piece goes off.

sp.speaker: Young For:
sp.p: Come descend; the pirate, fortune thou art then my friend. Now valiant friends and soldier's man the deck, draw up your fights, and lace your drablers on, whilst myself make good the forecastle, and ply my musket in the front of death, quarter yourselves in order, some abaft, some in the ships waste, all in martial order; our spright-sail top sail, and top-gallant, our mainsail, boar-spright, and our mizzen too are hung with waving pendants, and the colours of England and st. Georg ply in the stern. We fight against the foe we all desire,
sp.l: Alarum trumpets, gunner straight give fire. Exeunt.

div.stage: Alarm. Purser and Clinton with their mariners, all furnished with sea devices fitting for a fight.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Give them a full broadside; o Mr. gunner your upper tire of ordnance shot over; you gave not one shot betwixt wind and water in all this skirmish.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: Sir, you speak not well, I pierced them with my chase piece through and through; part of their capstring too I with a piece abaft shot overboard.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O 'twas a gallant shot, I saw it shatter some of their limbs in pieces: shall we grapple, and lay their ship aboard? where be these irons to hook 'em fast?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: I fear they're too well maned; for see the gunner ready to give fire unto their murderers if we stay to board 'em: shall we set sail and leave 'em.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: How can we when our ship has sprung a leak? being ready now to founder in the sea; some ply the pump: o for one lucky bullet to take their mainmast off; he that can make it shall have a treble share in this next prize.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.p: I shall go near it from my lower tire.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Gunner do that, 'tis all that we desire. Exeunt.

div.stage: Alarum: enter young Forrest and his mariners.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.p: Where is the gunner captain?

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: Where he should not be, at his prayers I think: is this a time to pray, when the sea's mouth seems to spit fire, and all the billows burn. Come hand with me, and we will board the pirates instantly.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.p: Hoist up more sails, and fetch 'em roundly up, and with their gallant vessel grapple straight.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: I spy the pirates in the very prow and forehead of their ship, both wafting us with their bright swords: now steersman take thy turn; and boatswain with your baser trumpets sound mingle your whistles shrill, o 'tis a music the mermaids love.

sp.speaker: 1. Mar.
sp.p: Who hates it that's a soldier?

sp.speaker: 2. Mar.
sp.l: Thy linstock gunner, take thy level right,
The wind is ours to help us in the fight.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: It blows a stiff gale, it makes all for us, every commander once more to his charge, he that this day shall die dies honourably; the cannons basilisks, and ordnance shall toll his funeral peal, and some now sound, shall die three deaths in one, shot, burned, and drowned.
sp.l: Come spare no powder till you see our ship,
Whose hard tough ribs hewed from the heart of oak,
Now black with pitch be painted blue with smoke. Exeunt.

div.stage: A great alarum, and flourish. Enter young forest and his mates with Purser and Clinton with their mariners prisoners.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: First thanks to heaven for this great victory bought with the fearful hazard of our lives, and large expense of blood on either part.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: We now are captives that made others thrall,
Thus ebbs may flow, and highest tides may fall.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: The latest day must come to have his date;
Stars govern all, and none can change his fate.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: Such prisoners as these pirates keep in hold, release them straight, the riches of their ship we amongst you will divide in equal shares, to every man's desert, estate, and place.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Fortune I spit defiance in thy face: thy best we have tasted, an thy worst we know, we can but pay what we to nature owe.

div.stage: Enter the merchant brought in with other prisoners.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: Surprised again, whose prisoner am I now? I am fortune's ball, whither am I bandied, having lost all before, is't possible that I can now be made a second prize? I lost my wealth in my first hostile strife,
sp.l: And nothing now is left me save my life.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: These prisoners we will at our further leisure peruse and know their fortunes and estates.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: That captain I should know, that face of his is with mine eye familiar, sure 'tis he whose life I by my sister's means preserved, with money and apparel furnished him, and got him place at sea and hath he now forgotten me, what not know me, the world right, when rich we honour, being poor we spite: ne'er look so strange, I do not mean to claim acquaintance of such men as are ingrate: all my good deeds once done I throw behind, whose meed in heaven, not earth I look to find.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: That merchant I have known, and now I better survey him, 'tis the man to whom I owe all that I have, my fortunes, nay my life; what reason have you sir to fly me so, since unto you, and to my brother's wife, my hopes, my power, my whole estate is due,
sp.l: From whom my means and all my fortunes grew.

sp.speaker: Me●.
sp.l: Do you know me then.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: Think you I can forget, or slightly cancel such a countless debt, behold my ship, my conquest, and my prize, these prisoners with my full command is yours;
sp.l: Yours, only yours, they at your service rest,
Alas dear friend how came you thus distressed?

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: These pirates robbed me, and have seized my goods with which they have stuffed their hold; my brother's venture with mine own substance they have made their spoil.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: All which behold I redeliver you, and to the utmost farthing will restore; besides I make you partner in our prize, and herein am I only fortunate to prove a grateful debtor.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: Your gratitude exceeds all courtesy, both of my sister's party and my own.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: It comes much short of either; o dear sir should I forget your friendship showed in want, and done in my extremest poverty, it were a sin, of heaven unpardonable; this pirate's ship load with your merchandise you shall straight man for England; where arrived, commend me to the mirror of her sex, your sister, in the humblest phrase you can, to whom deliver, as from me, this jewel, the best our voyage yields; tell her from me, that gentleman whose innocent life she saved, hath by that token her remembrance craved, to my brother, and my sister this small sum to buy their service from their father's hand, and free them from his slavish servitude.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: I shall do all your will, and thus overswayed,
Needs must report your debts are doubly paid.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.l: Having my pardon purchased, and my prisoners delivered to the sentence of the law, my next affairs shall be to visit her.

sp.speaker: Purs.
sp.l: Our case is otherwise, our next affairs
Is to betake us to our beads and prayers.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.l: Be as be may, base fortune I defy,
We bravely lived and I'll as boldly die.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.l: Hoist sail for England with our long wished prize,
Whilst we applaud that fortune he defies. Exe.

div.stage: Enter old Mr. Harding, Anne his wife, Foster and Goodwin, William and John, Philip and Susan's setting forth a table.

sp.speaker: Old hard
sp.p: You're welcome gentlemen, come take your places as your degrees are: wife the chair is yours; my loving boys sit, let th' servants wait.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Brother, that's you.

sp.speaker: Old hard
sp.p: This day I do entreat you gentlemen after the tables ended, to be witness unto some deeds that must inherit these, and him that is my eldest quite disable, to which I must entreat your friendly hands.

sp.speaker: Fost.
sp.p: Mine still is at your service.

sp.speaker: Goo●w.
sp.p: So is mine sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: O day long looked for.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Now shall we live like two young emperors; o day worthy to be writ in the almanac in red letters for a most famous holiday.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Well jest on gentlemen, when all is tried,
I hope my patience shall exceed your pride.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Wait at my elbow with a clean trencher Phil: do your duty, and have your due, you know your place, be ready with a glass of beer, and when I say fill, fill.

div.stage: Enter the clown.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: If please your worship here is a manner, or a kind of some foul desire to have some conference with you.

sp.speaker: Old hard
sp.p: A sea foul?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Yes a seagull, I mean a mariner, he says he hath some news to tell you from my mistress her brother at sea.

sp.speaker: Old hard
sp.p: Touching my venture, prithee guide him in.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: He smells as they say of pitch and tar, if you will have him to perfume the room with his sea musk. I'll show him the way instantly.

sp.speaker: Old hard
sp.p: I prithee do, and that with expedition.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: I did not look thus soon to hear from him.

sp.speaker: Old Hard
sp.p: I fear some strange mishap hath late befallen him.

div.stage: Enter sailor and the clown.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Now honest friend the news, how fares my brother?

sp.speaker: Old hard
sp.p: How doth my venture prosper?

sp.speaker: Sailor
sp.p: Sir, your ship is taken, all your goods by pirates seized, your brother prisoner, and of all your venture there's not the value of one penny saved.

sp.speaker: Old hard
sp.p: That news hath pierced my soul, and entered me quite through my heart, I am on the sudden sick, sick of I fear a mortal malady; o, o.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: How is it with my father?

sp.speaker: Old hard
sp.p: Worse and worse, the news of such a great and weighty loss kills all my vitals in me.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Father, for heaven's sake father die not yet before you have made over your land.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: That were a jest indeed, why father, father?

sp.speaker: Old Har.
sp.p: Trouble me not, if I survive this night, you two shall be my heirs.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: This night if it be thy will.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Alas, how fare you sir?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Take courage father.

sp.speaker: Old Harr.
sp.p: Son lead me hence, and bear me to my bed, my strength doth fail, I cannot help myself.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Run, run for the writings, they are ready drawn at the scriveners, bid him bring them quickly with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Old hard
sp.p: Let them alone, my hand hath not the strength to guide my pen, let them alone I say, support me to my bed, and my kind neighbours,
sp.l: Assist me with your prayers, for I divine
My soul this night shall amongst angels shine.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: Marry heaven forbid, can he find no time to die but now? come let's in, and haunt his ghost about the writings. Exe. man. Good. And Fost.

sp.speaker: Fost.
sp.p: 'Tis strange the bare report of such a loss should strike a man so deeply to the heart.

sp.speaker: Goodw.
sp.p: I oft have read the like, how some have died with sudden joy, some with exceeding grief.

sp.speaker: F●st
sp.p:
If he should die intestate, all the land falls to the elder brother,
and the younger have nothing save mere from his courtesy.

sp.speaker: Goodw.
sp.p: I know it, neither lands nor movables. Come let's hear what further news within. Enter the clown.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O my master, my master, what shall I do for my poor master, the kind churl is departed, never did poor hard-hearted wretch part out of the world so like a lamb; alas for my poor usuring, extortioning master, many an old widow hast thou turned into the street, and many an orphan made beg their bread; o my sweet, cruel, kind, pitiless, loving, hard hearted master, he's dead, he's dead, he's gone, he's fled and now full low must lie his head. O my sweet, vild, kind flinty, mild, uncharitable master.

sp.speaker: Fost.
sp.p: Dead on the sudden! 'tis exceeding strange, yet for the eldest son it happens well.

sp.speaker: Goodw.
sp.p: Ill for the younger brother. Enter Jack and Will.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Jack.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Will.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: The land's gone.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Father's dead.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: We have made a fair hand on't, have we not? who shall fill the glass now, and wait upon our trenchers?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nay who must go to plough, and make clean the hen-roost, rub horse-heels, lead the wains, remove the billets, cleanse the shoules, and and indeed who must do all the drudgery about the house?

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Could he find no time to die but now? I could even cry for anger: here they come. Enter Phil. and Sus. well habited. Anne and others.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: My father's dead.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Alas for my dear husband.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Comfort yourself, although he die intestate it shall not hurt you; we have found you kind, and shall be now as willing to requite you, as able: how now brothers, do you weep? and bear a part with us in heaviness? no, no, your griefs and ours is contrary; I grieve I have lost a father, she a husband, this doth not move you; you lamenting stand, not for a father's loss, but loss of land: do you remember with what rude despite, what base contempt, and slavish contumely you have despised me and my dear loved wife.

sp.speaker: Iac
sp.p: We partly remember it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: So do not I; I have forgotten it quite, in sign whereof, though had you got my lands, heaven knows how ill you would have dealt with me, thus I'll use you receive your patrimony.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No more fellow Phil now, but here receive your proportions.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Your diet if you please is at my table, or where you please if you refuse my kindness.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Kindness unlooked for, thanks gentle brother. Jack, why this gold will never be spent.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O it is an easy thing to bring this mountain to a molehill.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: This is more of your courtesy than our deserving, to trouble your table being so many ordinaries in town, were somewhat superfluous.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Spend but in compass, rioting eschew, waste not, but seek to increase your patrimony, beware of dice and women; company with men of best desert and quality; lay but these words in your hearts enrolled, you'll find them better than these bags of gold.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: Thanks for your coin and counsel: come Jack this shall be lavished among the suburbs; here's drink money, dice money, and drab money, here's money by the back, and money by the belly; here's that shall make us merry in claret. Muskadine, and sherry: farewell, brother.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: My most bounteous brother.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Farewell young masters.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And now my vild friends, such as fawn on plenty, and cannot bear the very name of want.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: We have found the mine now.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You that disabled once the power of heaven, and scorned my state unable to be raised.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You see here's your tale, and your talesman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Take heed lest here for your unthankfulness, that once raised, do not remove your estates (God be with you) henceforth howe'er you speed, trust not in riches, and despise not need.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: One threescore pound will do't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Mother, the thirds of all my father's lands are yours; with whatsoever you like else; and now sweet Sue it glads me I shall make thee partner of all this plenty that borest part with me in all extreme necessities.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: You are all my wealth, nor can I taste of want whilst I keep you; oh would these fortunes raise my down cast father, or repeal my brother, my banished brother to his native home, I were in all my thoughts at peace with heaven.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: All that I have is theirs; my only sorrow, next to my father, is in part for them, and next for your dear brother ta'en at sea, whose loss if he survive we will repair even with the best of our ability; but come unto our father's burial first, whom though his life brought sorrow, death content, we cannot but with funeral tears lament.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: And now no fellows unless it be at football. Enter merchant.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Heaven being just could not deal longer roughly with one so virtuous and completely honest, he merits all he hath, but to my state. I am at once doubly unfortunate, I have lost a husband and a brother too.

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: A husband, sister, but no brother, lo that brother lives.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: And can it heaven be so?

sp.speaker: Mr.
sp.p: You are the cause I live.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: I brother? how? tidings were brought into this place but now your ship was spoiled, you prisoner.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: And 'twas true, yet all these losses I regained by you.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: By me?

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: By you and sister thus it was; you saved the life of a young gentleman whom for your sake I furnished out to sea, he when my ship was taken, I surprised, and bound, and cast in hold, restored my fortunes, and besides all my merchandise restored, wherein you bore chief venture, made me sharer of the rich pirate's prize.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: That gentleman!

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: The self same in whose life you did save yourself some thousand pounds, I have as further token of his gratitude, in this choice jewel he commends to you millions of gratulations and kind thanks, besides unto his sister store of gold to redeem her wretched husband and herself from my deceased brother's slavery, which now I see pale death hath done for them.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: You speak of unexpected novelties, with which we will acquaint their sorrowful souls; these tokens will be joyful to them both, and tidings of his safety welcomer than that great sum by him regained at sea.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.l: We do them wrong to keep news of such joy
So long from them, which we'll no longer smother,
Two thousand pounds I bring you and a brother. Exeunt.

div.head: Scen. 1.
div.stage: Enter the sheriffs, the silver oar, Purser and Clinton going to execution.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Now how is't with thee Clinton?

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Well, well.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: But was't not better when we reigned as lords, nay Kings at sea, the ocean was our realm, and the light billows in the which we sailed our hundreds, nay our shires, and provinces, that brought us annual profit, those were days.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Yes golden days, but now our last night's come, and we must sleep in darkness.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Worthy mate we have a flash left of some half hour long, that let us burn out bravely, not behind us leave a black noisome snuff of cowardice ith' nostrils of our noble countrymen; let's die no base example.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Thinks Tom wanton, whom storms could never move, tempests daunt, rocks terrify nor swallowing gulfs affright, to whom the base abyss in roughest rage showed like a pleasant garden in a calm, and the sea-monsters but like beasts at land of profit or pleasure Clinton can be affrighted with a halter? hemp him strangle that thinks of him so basely.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: In that word thou hast put a second sentence of our lives; yet Clinton never was't my thoughts of thee: o the naval triumphs thou and I have seen, nay ourselves made, when on the seas at once have been as many bonfires as in towns, kindled upon a night of jubilee, as many ordnance thundering in the clouds as at Kings coronations, and dead bodies heaved from the hatches, and cast overboard, as fast and thick as in some common pest when the plague sweeps cities.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: That it had swept us then too, so the seas had been to us a glorious monument, where now the fates have cast us on the shelf to hang 'twixt air and water.

sp.speaker: Sher.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your limited hour draws nigh.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: I that's the plague we spoke of, yet no greater than some before have tasted, and hereafter many be bound to suffer (And if Purser, as dying men seldom deem amiss) presage not wrong, how many gallant spirits, equal with us in fame, shall this gulf swallow, and make this silver oar to blush in blood? how many captains that have awed the seas shall fall on this infortunate piece of land? some that commanded lands, some to whom the Indian mines paid tribute, Turk veiled: but when we that have quaked, nay troubled floods, and made armadoes fly before our stream, shall founder thus, be split and lost,
sp.l: Then be it no impeachment to their fame,
Since Purser and bold Clinton bide the same.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: What is our ship well tackled? we may launch upon this desperate voyage.

sp.speaker: Hangman
sp.p: Corded bravely.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Call up the boatswain, soundly lash the slave with a rope's end; have him unto the chest, or duck him at the mainyard.

sp.speaker: Hangman
sp.p: Have me to the chest, I must first have you to the gallows, and for ducking, I'm afraid I shall see you ducked and draked too.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: O you brave navigators that have seen, or ever had yourselves command aboard, that knew our empire there, and our fall now, pity at least us that are made the scorn of a base common hangman.

sp.speaker: Sheriff
sp.p: Thou dost ill to offend them in their deaths.

sp.speaker: Hangman
sp.p: I have, and long to make an end of them.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Hadst thou but two months since wrinkled a brow, looked but askew, much less unloosed thy lips to speak, speak said I? nay but lodged a thought, or murmur of the least affront to us, thee, basest of all worm's meat, I had made unwholesome food for haddocks: but I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: Enough Tom Watton, with these sheets not sails, a stiff gale blows to split us on yon rock.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p:
And set sail from the fatal marshal seas, and Wapping is our harbour,
a quick sand that shall swallow many a brave marine soldier, of whose valour, experience, skill, and naval discipline, being lost, I wish this land may never have need: but what star must we sail by? or what compass?

sp.speaker: Hangman
sp.p: I know not the star, but here's your compass.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: Yes that way points the needle, that way we steer a sad course, plague of the pilot; hear you Mr. sheriff, you see we wear good clothes, they are paid for, and our own, then give us leave our own amongst our friends to distribute: there's, sir, for you.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: And you.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: The work man made them took never measure on a hangman's back; wear them for our sakes, and remember us; there's some content for him too.

sp.speaker: Hangman
sp.p: Thank your worships.

sp.speaker: Clin.
sp.p: I would your knaveship had our worships place, if hanging now be held so worshipful.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p: But now our sun is all setting, night comes on, the watery wilderness o'er which we reigned, proves in our ruins peaceful, Mr. Chantes trade fearless abroad as in the river's mouth, and free as in a harbour, then fair Thames, Queen of fresh water, famous through the world, and not the least through us, whose double tides must overflow our bodies, and being dead, may thy clear waves our scandals wash away, but keep our valours living; now lead on Clinton, thus arm in arm let's march to death, and wheresoe'er our names are memorised,
sp.l: The world report two valiant pirates fell,
Shot betwixt wind and water; so farewell. Exeunt as they entered.

div.stage: Enter old Forrest and young Forrest.

sp.speaker: Old For.
sp.p: A father's blessing, more than all thy honours crown thee, and make thy fortunes growing still: o heavens I shall be too importunate to ask more earthly favours at your hands; now that you after all these miseries have still reserved my son safe and unscorned. Besides thy pardon and thy country's freedom, what favours hath her grace conferred on thee?

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: More than my pardon and the meed proposed, to grace the rest, she styled me with the order of knighthood, and for the service of my country, with promise of employments of more weight: the pirates were committed to the Marshalseas, condemned already, and this day to die: and now as part of my neglected duty, it rests I visit that fair gentlewoman to whom I stand indebted for my life; that necessary duty once performed, out of my present fortunes to distribute some present comfort to my sister's wants.

sp.speaker: Old For.
sp.p: A grateful friend thou art, a kind dear brother, and a most loving son.

div.stage: Enter Philip, Susan, merchant, Anne.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sir, more than all these fortunes now befallen me, a fate 'Midst all disaster unexpected, my noble brother's late success at sea hath filled me with a surplusage of joy, nor am I least of all endeared to you, to be the first reporter.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: 'Tis most true, and I the man that in the most distress had first share of his bounty.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Of his goodness we have had sufficient taste already, but to be made more happy in his sight would plenally rejoice us.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: It would prove like surfeit after sweet meats.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: See all my friends, but first let me salute her to whom I am most bound.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: My most dear father.

sp.speaker: Old For.
sp.p: My blessings meeting with a husband's love make thy years long and happy.

sp.speaker: Anne
sp.p: You are most grateful, and much beyond my merit.

sp.speaker: S●s.
sp.p: O spare me, sir, to ●y into his arms that hath so long fled from me.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: My sweet sister.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Bar me not all the best fruition of what in part you have tasted: sir, I am one amongst the rest that love you.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: I take't my sister's husband, unto me therefore one most entired.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: Sir the same, and I though last in my acknowledgement, yet first in due arrearage.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: You I know to be a worthy merchant and my friend, to whose, next to your sister's courtesy I stand engaged most for a forfeit life: but he next to the powers divine above, I ever must adore; and now fair creature I dare more boldly look upon the face of your good man then when I saw you last.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: And that's some question.

sp.speaker: Yo●ng For.
sp.p: Wherefore hath that word struck you with sudden sadness.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: My husband!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: He's late dead, and yet hath left her none of the poorest widows.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: Dead did you say, and I a bachelor, now on whom better or justlier can I confer myself, than to be hers by whom I have my being, and live to her that freely gave me life? there is a providence that prompts to't, and I will give it motion: gentle lady, by you I am, and what I am by you, be then to me as I have styled you last, a Lady● heavens have made you my preserver, to preserve me for yourself, losing a husband, who knows but you have saved me to that end, that lost name to recover; and by me sweet interchange and double gratitude: I left you sped, but find you now despoiled: married you ventured for my single life; widowed, by me to gain the name of wife.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: What, pause you at the motion? you are not my sister if you deny him.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Let me plead for him.

sp.speaker: Sus.
sp.p: O doubly link me to you, be you styled my brother and my father.

sp.speaker: Old For.
sp.p: With you let my age join, and make me proud to say, that in my last of days, barren of issue, I have got so fair a daughter.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: Sweet, your answer.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Sir, I should much mistake my own fair ends,
Should I alone withstand so many friends.
I am yours, and only so.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: I yours the same, and lady now I kiss you by that name. Enter clown.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: What kissing already! then I smell another wedding towards, and in no fitter time than now: prepare yourselves gentlemen and gentlewomen; make a hall; for I come to present you with a mask.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What mask?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Not such as ladies wear upon their faces, to keep the foul from the fair, but a plain mask, or rather more properly I may call it a muming, because the presenters have scarce a word to speak for themselves.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: If there be any that appear as friends, and come to grace our feast in courtesy, admit 'em prithee.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: That shall I sir, and with all expedition,
And that without drum, without fife, or musician.
sp.p: These two lines shall serve for the prologue: now enter scaena prima, dramatis personae; these be the actors, yet let me entreat you not to condemn them before you hear them speak.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Amazement startles me: are these my brothers?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: By the father's side it should seem; for you know he was a hard man, and it should seem 'tis but a hard world with them.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And these my false friends that distrusted heaven, and put their faith in riches; I pray gentlemen how comes this change?

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: How comes this change say you? no change of pastors, which they say makes fat calves, but change of drink, change of women, change of ordinaries, change of gaming, and one wench in the change● all these helped to make this change in us.

sp.speaker: Will
sp.p: And change is no robbery, I have been robbed, but not at ruff, yet they that have robbed you see what a poor stock they have left me: a whore stole away my maidenhead, ill company my good conditions, a broker robbed me of my apparel, drink of my wits, and dice of my money.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: This is no more than expectation: but how come you thus altered?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: If you had said haltered, sir, you had gone more roundly to the business.

sp.speaker: Fost.
sp.p: Sir, there was coining laid to my charge, for which (Though I acquit myself) I made my estate over unto a friend (For so I thought him) but now he has cozened me, and turned me out of all.

sp.speaker: Goodw.
sp.p: In dead of night my counting house was broke ope by thieves, and all my coin (Which was my whole estate, and god I then did trust in) stole away, I left a forlorn beggar.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O wondrous, why this passes.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: It may pass amongst the rest for a scurvy jest, but never like mother passes ale, for that was knighted.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: Ale knighted! how I prithee?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: You have heard of ale knights, therefore it is not improbable that ale may be knighted.

sp.speaker: Merchant
sp.p: Thy reason?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why there is ale in the town that passes from man to man, from lip to lip, and from nose to nose, but mother passes double ale I assure you, surpasses, therefore knighted.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Leave trifling, for more serious is the object offered before our eyes: in these heaven's justice, in these a most remarkable precedent to teach within our height to know ourselves; of which I make this use; you are my brothers (A name you once disdained to call me by) your wants shall be relieved: you that distrusted heavens providence, and made a mock of want and others misery, no more deride; part of your loss shall be by me supplied according to my power.

sp.speaker: Young For.
sp.p: My noble brother, you teach us virtue, of which I could wish all those that see good days make happy use, so those distressed; for both there's precedent, but to our present nuptials; reverent father dear lady, sister, friend, nay brothers too, but you sir, most conjoined and endeared.
sp.l: In us the world may see our fates well scanned,
Fortune in me by sea, in you by land. Exeunt omnes.
